com.bluegosling.tuples

Class Pair<A,B>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.bluegosling.tuples.Pair<A,B>
  • Type Parameters:
    A - the type of the first item
    B - the type of the second item
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Tuple, Tuple.Ops1<A>, Tuple.Ops2<A,B>, Serializable, Iterable<Object>

    @ValueType
public final class Pair<A,B>
extends Object
implements Tuple.Ops2<A,B>, Serializable
    A tuple with two items.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • asTypedList

        public static <T> List<T> asTypedList(Pair<? extends T,? extends T> pair)
        Returns a list with a tighter upper bound than Tuple.asList().

        Due to limitations in expressiveness of lower bounds and wildcards in Java's generic type system, achieving the right bounds must be done as a static method.

        Parameters:
        pair - a pair of items
        Returns:
        a list view of the specified pair

      • separate

        public static <T,U> Pair<List<T>,List<U>> separate(Collection<Pair<T,U>> pairs)
        Separates the values in a collection of pairs to produce a pair of collections. The returned lists will have the same size as the specified collection and items will be in the same order as returned by iteration over the specified collection (e.g. the first items in the returned lists represent the items extracted from the first pair in the collection).
        Parameters:
        pairs - a collection of pairs
        Returns:
        a pair of lists whose values were extracted from the collection of pairs

      • combine

        public static <T,U> List<Pair<T,U>> combine(Pair<? extends Collection<T>,? extends Collection<U>> pair)
        Combines a pair of collections into a collection of pairs. The returned list will have the same size as the specified collections and items will be in the same order as returned by iteration over the specified collections (e.g. the first pair in the returned list is a pair with the first value from each collection).
        Parameters:
        pair - a pair of collections
        Returns:
        a list of pairs, each one representing corresponding values from the collections
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the two collections have different sizes

      • combine

        public static <T,U> List<Pair<T,U>> combine(Collection<T> t,
                                            Collection<U> u)
        Combines two collections into a collection of pairs. The returned list will have the same size as the specified collections and items will be in the same order as returned by iteration over the specified collections (e.g. the first pair in the returned list is a pair with the first value from each collection).
        Parameters:
        t - a collection whose elements will constitute the first value of a pair
        u - a collection whose elements will constitute the second value of a pair
        Returns:
        a list of pairs, each one representing corresponding values from the collections
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the two collections have different sizes

      • contains

        public boolean contains(Object o)
        Description copied from interface: Tuple
        Determines if this tuple contains the specified object. The tuple contains the object if any of the tuple's items is equal to the object. (An item e1 is equal to an object e2 if (e1==null ? e2==null : e1.equals(e2)).)
        Specified by:
        contains in interface Tuple
        Parameters:
        o - the object
        Returns:
        true if any of the items in this tuple are equal to the specified object

      • add

        public <T> Triple<A,B,T> add(T t)
        Description copied from interface: Tuple
        Adds a new item to this tuple. The item will be appended and thus ordered last in the new tuple. Since tuples are immutable, a new tuple is returned with the same items as this tuple but with the specified item added to the end.
        Specified by:
        add in interface Tuple
        Specified by:
        add in interface Tuple.Ops1<A>
        Specified by:
        add in interface Tuple.Ops2<A,B>
        Parameters:
        t - the item to add
        Returns:
        a new tuple that is the specified item appended to this tuple

      • insertFirst

        public <T> Triple<T,A,B> insertFirst(T t)
        Description copied from interface: Tuple
        Adds an item into the first position of this tuple. Existing items are shifted over so the first item in this tuple is the second item in the returned tuple. Since tuples are immutable, a new tuple is returned with the same items as this tuple but with the specified item inserted as the first item.
        Specified by:
        insertFirst in interface Tuple
        Specified by:
        insertFirst in interface Tuple.Ops1<A>
        Specified by:
        insertFirst in interface Tuple.Ops2<A,B>
        Parameters:
        t - the item to insert
        Returns:
        a new tuple that is the specified item followed by the items in this tuple

      • insertSecond

        public <T> Triple<A,T,B> insertSecond(T t)
        Description copied from interface: Tuple.Ops1
        Inserts an item into the second position of this tuple. Since tuples are immutable, this returns a new tuple with one more item.

        If this tuple has only one item then this is the same as calling Tuple.Ops1.add(Object). Otherwise, this will insert an item after the first item but before the second.

        Specified by:
        insertSecond in interface Tuple.Ops1<A>
        Specified by:
        insertSecond in interface Tuple.Ops2<A,B>
        Parameters:
        t - the new item
        Returns:
        a new tuple with the same items as this tuple except the specified new item is inserted as the second item in the tuple

      • insertThird

        public <T> Triple<A,B,T> insertThird(T t)
        Description copied from interface: Tuple.Ops2
        Inserts an item into the third position of this tuple. Since tuples are immutable, this returns a new tuple with one more item.

        If this tuple has only two items then this is the same as calling Tuple.Ops2.add(Object). Otherwise, this will insert an item after the second item but before the third.

        Specified by:
        insertThird in interface Tuple.Ops2<A,B>
        Parameters:
        t - the new item
        Returns:
        a new tuple with the same items as this tuple except the specified new item is inserted as the third item in the tuple

      • transformAll

        public <T> Pair<T,T> transformAll(Function<Object,? extends T> function)
        Description copied from interface: Tuple
        Transforms every item in this tuple by applying the specified function to each one. Since tuples are immutable, a new tuple is returned. The returned tuple will have the same number of items as this tuple.
        Specified by:
        transformAll in interface Tuple
        Specified by:
        transformAll in interface Tuple.Ops1<A>
        Specified by:
        transformAll in interface Tuple.Ops2<A,B>
        Parameters:
        function - the function to apply
        Returns:
        a new tuple that is the result of applying the specified function to all elements of this tuple

        Parameters:

      • toArray

        public <T> T[] toArray(T[] a)
        Description copied from interface: Tuple
        Returns an array of the items in this tuple. The runtime type of the returned array is that of the specified array. If the tuple's elements fits in the specified array, they are returned therein. Otherwise, a new array is allocated with the runtime type of the specified array and the size of this collection.

        If this tuple fits in the specified array with room to spare (i.e., the array has more elements than this tuple), the element in the array immediately following the last element of the tuple is set to null. (This is useful in determining the length of this tuple only if the caller knows that this tuple does not contain any null elements.)

        Specified by:
        toArray in interface Tuple
        Parameters:
        a - an array with the desired runtime type
        Returns:
        an array of the items in this tuple
        See Also:
        Collection.toArray(Object[])

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object o)
        Description copied from interface: Tuple
        Compares this tuple with the specified object. If the specified object is also a Tuple and has the same items as this tuple in the same order, then this tuple is equal to the specified object. (Two elements e1 and e2 are equal if (e1==null ? e2==null : e1.equals(e2)).)
        Specified by:
        equals in interface Tuple
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        o - the object to which this tuple is compared
        Returns:
        true if the specified object is a tuple and has the same items

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Description copied from interface: Tuple
        Returns the hash code value for this tuple. The hash code should be computed like so: Arrays.hashCode(tuple.toArray()). This is effectively the same as List.hashCode() for a list with the same items and in the same order as this tuple.
        Specified by:
        hashCode in interface Tuple
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        the hash code for this tuple
